column4: The Bush Administration has been talking about the threat of nuclear terrorism on American soil for years. On September 8th, 2002, Condoleezza Rice sounded a strong warning. She was talking about Iraq then, but a nuclear attack inside America is a very real concern for top level security experts now."It's not a matter of if, it's a matter of when" says one anti-terror expert. Defense expert Graham Allison believes not enough has been done to prevent the unthinkable.Click one of the "Listen" links to hear about the very real threat of nuclear terror on American soil, and what can be done to stop it.Â·Graham Allison, Director of the Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, former Assistant Secretary of Defense for Policy and Plans and author of "Nuclear Terrorism: The Ultimate Preventable Catastrophe."Two days ago, President Bush announced the biggest troop realignment since the Cold War before the annual convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars in Cincinnati, OH. Today, his Democratic opponent, John Kerry, used the same venue to blast Bush's plan.Bush said he wants to withdraw 70,000 troops from Europe and Asia over the next ten years. Kerry told the VFW today that "nobody wants to bring troops home more than those of us who have fought in foreign wars. But it needs to be done at the right time and in the right way."Tune in to hear more of Kerry's address, as well as commentary from Joe Hallet, chief political writer at the Columbus Dispatch, who was at Kerry's speech today.Security was tight at Belmarsh Magistrates Court, where the eight suspects were charged with, among other things, possessing plans for targets such as the IMF in Washington, the New York Stock Exchange, the Citibank building in New York and the Prudential Building in New Jersey. The eight men were remanded without bail until their preliminary hearing on August 25.Guardian reporter Tanya Branigan was at the court and describes the security precautions as the suspects were brought to trial.
